Daud Kilau – Puji Siti Nurhaliza dalam lagu.|url=http://www.simplysiti.com/m-daud-kilau-puji-siti-nurhaliza-dalam-lagu/|language=ms|author=Rosli Manah|work=Utusan|accessdate=29 April 2010}} * [[KRU]]'s ''Empat Syarat''{{cite web|title=Tawaran macho KRU.|url=http://www.nib.com.my/archives/text/view/4355452?pos=5&hide_header=1&resultset=nstpec%3Awww/cross-search/search.php%3A_1279114186%3Aresultset|language=ms|date=13 February 2005|publisher=Digital Collections DC5: Text Archive|accessdate = 14 July 2010}} ===International performances=== By far, she has been thrice to be invited to perform at the MTV Asia Awards, which are in 2003, where she sang her debut, ''Bukan Cinta Biasa'', in 2004 where she performed together with Gareth Gates and her 2005 solo performance with ''Seindah Biasa'', one of her singles from her tenth solo album, [[Prasasti Seni]].{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza Artis Pilihan Malaysia kali ke-5|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2005&dt=0204&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_10.htm|language=ms|date=3 February 2005|work=Utusan Online| accessdate = 2 August 2010}} However, one of her earliest performances at an international stage is during the closing ceremony of 1998 Commonwealth Games where it was watched by more than 70 countries when she was only 19. 1999 was the year of her debut at the 'Shanghai Music Festival 1999' in China and the 'South Pacific International Song and Singing Competition 1999', where she garnered a 'Gold Award' and 'Best Female Vocal Performance' respectively. She also has performed in Australia, Brunei, China, Indonesia, Japan, Kazakhstan, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and United Kingdom. In March 2000, her first concert ever outside the Malaysian market in Singapore at [[HarbourFront Centre (Singapore)|Harbour Pavilion]] managed to outsold [[Mariah Carey]]'s [[Rainbow World Tour]] which was scheduled five days earlier{{cite web|title=Siti martabatkan lagu tradisional|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2000&dt=0325&pub=utusan_malaysia&sec=Hiburan&pg=et_01.htm&arc=hive|language=ms|author=Tengku Khalida Tengku Bidin|date=25 March 2000|work=Utusan Online| accessdate = 16 January 2012}} even though the most expensive tickets price was much higher than Carey's.{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza's Concert in Singapore Tipped For Sellout|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2000&dt=0305&pub=utusan_express&sec=Front_Page&pg=fp_10.htm&arc=hive|date=3 March 2000|work=Utusan Online| accessdate = 16 January 2012}} In May 2006, she was offered to perform together with Indian [[Bollywood]] star, [[Shah Rukh Khan]] in front of 300 [[Bollywood]] artists and guests along with 2.6 billion television viewers where she will be performing at 2nd [[Global Indian Film Awards]] 2006 in Kuala Lumpur.{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza to sing at Bollywood film awards|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/5/10/nation/14195934&sec=nation|date=6 May 2010|work=theStar Online|accessdate=20 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617200735/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2006%2F5%2F10%2Fnation%2F14195934&sec=nation|archivedate=17 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} However, the offer later was cancelled by Siti due to her commitment with other projects after informing the organizers beforehand.{{cite web|title=Siti hampakan Shah Rukh Khan|url=http://mstar.com.my/hiburan/cerita.asp?file=/2006/12/4/HIBURAN/m_Aduh/Siti_hampakan_Shah_Rukh_Khan&sec=mstar_hiburan|language=ms|author=Radin Sri Ghazali|date=4 December 2006|work=mStar Online|accessdate=29 April 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127182738/http://mstar.com.my/hiburan/cerita.asp?file=%2F2006%2F12%2F4%2FHIBURAN%2Fm_Aduh%2FSiti_hampakan_Shah_Rukh_Khan&sec=mstar_hiburan|archive-date=27 November 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===Wealth=== Siti is known to be a formidable and successful and well-known businesswoman in Malaysia. She currently tops the list of the 'Richest Artistes' in Malaysia. She is also reported to worth more than RM50 million as of 2010, enabling her to be named as one of the millionaires in entertainment industry, especially in the South East Asia region. As one of the most prolific artists in Malaysia, she is said to be paid RM 45,000 (USD$15 000) for a 30 minutes show and RM 70,000 (USD$23 333) for an hour show in 2009.{{cite web|title=The star will sing for you|url=http://www.nib.com.my/archives/text/view/1470830?pos=7&hide_header=1&resultset=nstpec%3Awww/cross-search/search.php%3A_1281025117%3Aresultset|author=Shuinb Taib|date=20 September 2009|work=New Straits Time|publisher=Digital Collections DC5: Cross Search|accessdate = 3 January 2010}} ==Other ventures== ===Products and endorsements=== With success in her singing career, Siti then got herself involved in business. She set up her own company – Siti Nurhaliza Productions (M) Sdn. Bhd. – with activities generally in the entertainment scene. She has four subsidiary companies, [[Siti Nurhaliza Collections|Siti Nurhaliza Collections Sdn. Bhd.]], Siti Nurhaliza Marketing Sdn. Bhd., Siti Sound Sdn. Bhd. and SN Mobile Digital Sdn. Bhd. She is also the president of her own cosmetic range company, Simply Siti Sdn. Bhd.{{cite web|title=Lima Warna Baru Lipstik SimplySiti Dilancar|url=http://mstar.com.my/hiburan/cerita.asp?file=/2010/10/1/mstar_hiburan/20100930201201&sec=mstar_hiburan|language=ms|date=1 October 2010|work=mStar Online|accessdate=19 October 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002105421/http://www.mstar.com.my/hiburan/cerita.asp?file=%2F2010%2F10%2F1%2Fmstar_hiburan%2F20100930201201&sec=mstar_hiburan|archive-date=2 October 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Siti sells her own tea, Ctea,{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza introduces Ctea|url=http://old.brudirect.com/public_html/DailyInfo/News/Archive/Aug05/070805/nite22.htm|author=Sang Dewi & Rosh Abidin Yahya|work=BruDirect.com|accessdate=28 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406192825/http://old.brudirect.com/public_html/DailyInfo/News/Archive/Aug05/070805/nite22.htm|archivedate=6 April 2010|df=dmy-all}} brand of Malaysian tea, from tea cultivated on the foothills of [[Mount Kinabalu]], Sabah. This Ctea brand comes in two flavours, Geranium Special and [[Screwpine|Pandan]]. And now besides having her own products, she receives substantial income through commissions and royalties for her endorsements and as ambassador of products. She has been an ambassador and spokesperson for various international products{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza Tarudin Official|url=http://www.facebook.com/pages/Siti-Nurhaliza-Tarudin-Official/126837781389#/pages/Siti-Nurhaliza-Tarudin-Official/126837781389?v=info|work=Facebook|accessdate = 28 December 2009}} – [[Jusco]], [[Maxis Communications|Maxis]], [[Maybelline]], [[Minolta]], [[Mitsubishi]], [[Olay]], [[Pantene]], [[Pepsi]], [[Samsung]] and [[TM Net]]. {{clear}} ==Philanthropy== [[File:Siti Nurhaliza Khai.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Siti Nurhaliza during the Malay Mail Big Walk 2007, a charity event to collect some donations for children with bone cancer.{{cite web|title=THE MALAY MAIL BIG WALK 2007|url=http://www.pacesetters.com.my/resource/news/mmbw.htm|date=22 April 2007|work=Pacesetters – Athletic Club Malaysia|accessdate=17 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722231456/http://www.pacesetters.com.my/resource/news/mmbw.htm|archivedate=22 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}]] Throughout her career, she has been involved in a number of charity-related event, including organising charity concerts,{{Cite news|title=Siti to host two charity concerts in T'ganu.|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-127965461/siti-host-two-charity.html|date=30 January 2005|work=Bernama|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|accessdate = 13 May 2013}} open houses{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza, Datuk K teruskan tradisi hulur zakat bantu penduduk|url=http://www.utusan.net.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0808&pub=utusan_malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_11.htm|language=ms|date=29 February 2008|work=Utusan Online|accessdate = 13 May 2013}} and launching her own charity funds.{{Cite news|title=Siti's broken promise.|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-20793948_ITM|date=24 March 2004|work=New Straits Time|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|accessdate = 13 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=DCHL lancar program kumpul dana bersama Yayasan Nurjiwa|url=http://www.simplysiti.com/dchl-lancar-program-kumpul-dana-bersama-yayasan-nurjiwa/|author=Nur Farhatul Aishati Azharie|language=ms|date=29 February 2008|publisher=Berita Harian|work=Simplysiti.com|accessdate = 11 June 2010}} In March 2004, she launched ''Tabung Prihatin Siti'', making her the first Malaysian artist to have a charity fund after her namesake whose aim to raise at least RM 50 000 for children's education and medical treatment. In January 2005, Nurhaliza donated [[Malaysian ringgit|RM]] 35 000 (about United States dollar11,000) to three different organisations for the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 tsunami]] victims before her concert at the Royal Albert Hall in April of the same year.{{Cite news|title=Songbird Siti chips in RM25 000|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-18509096_ITM|date=7 January 2005|work=New Straits Time|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|accessdate = 11 June 2010}} A year later in February, she donated RM 500 000 for the National Anti-Drug Campaign where she was also appointed as the ambassadress for the campaign.{{Cite news|title=Siti Nurhaliza Donates RM500 000 For National Anti Drug Campaign|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-142667539/siti-nurhaliza-donates-rm500000.html|date=19 February 2006|work=Bernama|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|accessdate = 11 June 2010}} Six months later, she and her husband founded Yayasan Nurjiwa (Nurjiwa Foundation) where the foundation served as a platform for people to help those in need through charity concerts and dinner events where the money will be donated to the selected organisations. In 2009, she and her husband donated RM 1.5 million to build a new mosque in Tikam Batu, [[Kuala Muda]] where the land was given as a ''[[Waqf|wakaf]]'' by both of them and Siti's mother-in-law where before this, her husband has also donated a sum of money to build two mosques in Kuala Lumpur and [[Pattani]], Thailand{{cite web|title=Siti Nurhaliza, suami sumbang RM1.5 juta bina masjid|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2009&dt=0521&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_33.htm|language=ms|date=20 May 2009|work=Utusan Online|accessdate = 11 June 2010}} which finally completed in February 2011 and officiated by Sultan of [[Kedah]], [[Abdul Halim of Kedah|Tuanku Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah]].{{cite web|title=Masjid dibiayai Siti dan Datuk K di Sungai Petani siap |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2009&dt=0521&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_33.htm|language=ms|date=20 February 2011|work=Utusan Online|accessdate = 25 February 2011}} In 2011, Siti and her husband gave out an undisclosed amount of ''[[Zakat]]'' (alms) to more than 200 elderly people, single mothers and disabled people in Tikam Batu as part of their tradition apart from providing them with [[sarong]], [[batik]] and some "Duit Raya" (pocket money during [[Eid al-Fitr]]) for the children. ==Personal life== ===Relationship with Khalid Mohamad Jiwa=== [[File:Siti Nurhaliza & Dato' Khalid.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Siti Nurhaliza and her husband, Datuk Khalid during the [[Malay Mail]] Big Walk in 2007.]] On 17 July 2006, after months of speculation by the media, Siti and her then-fiancé, Datuk Khalid made a press conference announcing that their wedding would be held on 21 August.{{cite web|title=Keluarga suka Siti|url=http://www.nib.com.my/archives/text/view/45917008?pos=5&hide_header=1&resultset=nstpec%3Awww/cross-search/search.php%3A_1284712231%3Aresultset|language=ms|date=18 July 2006|work=Harian Metro|publisher=Digital Collections DC5: Cross Search|accessdate = 17 September 2010}} Her plan to marry Datuk Khalid caused criticisms and uproar, since she was going to marry a 47-year-old divorcee with four sons{{cite web|title=Cerita sensasi panaskan dunia hiburan negara|url=http://www.nib.com.my/archives/text/view/29965842?pos=2&hide_header=1&resultset=nstpec%3Awww/cross-search/search.php%3A_1284712231%3Aresultset|language=ms|date=30 December 2006|work=Berita Harian|publisher=Digital Collections DC5: Cross Search|accessdate = 17 September 2010}} where she was accused of causing his divorce. However, the issue was rebutted when Jabatan Agama Islam Selangor (Selangor Islamic Council) verified that Datuk Khalid and his former wife, Tengku Zawyah Tengku Izham officially separated in February 2004, after 15 years of marriage.{{cite web|title=Datuk K tak perlu kebenaran berpoligami|url=http://www.nib.com.my/archives/text/view/29777879?pos=3&hide_header=1&resultset=nstpec%3Awww/cross-search/search.php%3A_1284712231%3Aresultset|language=ms|date=7 July 2006|work=Berita Harian|publisher=Digital Collections DC5: Cross Search|accessdate = 17 September 2010}} Some sources speculated that the total wedding cost was RM 12,888,888 (USD 3,947,980 (adjusted to 2010 inflation)),{{Cite news|title=DATUK K DENIES NEWS REPORT OF EXTRAVAGANT WEDDING|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-151795598/datuk-k-denies-news.html|date=12 August 2006|work=Bernama|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]| accessdate = 8 May 2010}} however it was later denied by the couple and the wedding planner and stated that the total cost was roughly around RM 500,000.{{Cite news|title=Princess of Pop's regal wedding|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-148349919/princess-pop-regal-wedding.html|author=Hafidah Samat|date=18 July 2006|work=Bernama|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]| accessdate = 8 May 2010}} Her wedding dowry was revealed to cost at RM 22,222 and the ''hantaran'' (gifts from groom to bride and vice versa) cost around RM 30,000. The total sponsored items including Siti and spouse's jewelleries, dresses, etc., cost more than RM 9 million.{{Cite news|title=In ringgit and sen|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-150564451/ringgit-and-sen.html|date=29 August 2006|work=New Straits Time|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]| accessdate = 8 May 2010}} Later, RM 1 million from the total price paid by TV3 to broadcast the whole ceremony was later donated to charity.{{Cite news|title=Fairy-tale wedding, no less|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-150886113/fairy-tale-wedding-no.html|date=2 September 2006|work=New Straits Time|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]| accessdate = 8 May 2010 | first=Suraya | last=Al-Attas}} The engagement ceremony was held at Masjid Wilayah Persekutuan ([[Federal Territory Mosque]]) on 21 August 2006. The ceremony was also televised live and gathered more than 2 millions viewers. The first wedding reception was held on 28 August 2006, at the [[Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre]] (KLCC). and was televised to 6.3 millions viewers nationwide.{{cite web | title=The Ratings are in: Siti 6.3 million Log | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/8/30/nation/15279128&sec=nation 14 | date=30 August 2006 | work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | accessdate=30 August 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014034436/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2006%2F8%2F30%2Fnation%2F15279128&sec=nation | archivedate=14 October 2007 | df=dmy-all }} The wedding also received coverage from Indonesia, where 10 Indonesian media representatives were there to capture the moment including [[Trans TV]], [[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]] and [[Jawa Pos]].{{cite web|title=Persandingan Siti – Datuk K meriah|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2006&dt=0829&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_01.htm|language=ms|date=29 August 2006|work=Utusan Online|accessdate = 3 May 2010}}{{cite web | title=Wedding Reception of Siti-Datuk K Steeped in Tradition | url=http://www.simplysiti.com/category/bernama/page/4/ | date=29 August 2006 | work=Bernama | accessdate=30 August 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100406173112/http://www.simplysiti.com/category/bernama/page/4/ | archivedate=6 April 2010 | df=dmy-all }} Photographed by celebrity photographer [[Kid Chan]],{{cite news|last=Khoo|first=Rubin|title=The kid grows up|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/1/20/yummy/20080119111950&sec=yummy|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130111204356/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/1/20/yummy/20080119111950&sec=yummy|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 January 2013|accessdate=3 January 2012|newspaper=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=20 January 2008}} it was a star-studded affair, with guests including royal families, VIPs, celebrities, close friends and family. Indonesian celebrities like [[Hetty Koes Endang]] and one of Siti's closest friends, Krisdayanti were given the opportunity to give a performance to the newlywed and guests. A second reception was held on 3 September 2006, in Siti's hometown of Kuala Lipis, Pahang where more than 10,000 people attended the ceremony including those from neighbouring countries.{{Cite news|title=10,000 attend Siti's reception|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-150887443/10000-attend-siti-reception.html|author=M. Hamzah Jamaludin|date=4 September 2006|work=New Straits Time|publisher=[[AccessMyLibrary]]| accessdate = 8 May 2010}} In the same year, the wedding charted as one of the 20 top celebrity weddings on [[Yahoo! Buzz]].{{cite web|title=Cinta Siti, Datuk K makin utuh|trans-title=Siti and Datuk K's Love is Growing Stronger|url=http://www.sinarharian.com.my/hiburan/cinta-siti-datuk-k-makin-utuh-1.422052|author=Sinar Harian Staff|date=21 August 2015|work=[[Sinar Harian]]}} In 2011, her wedding was also listed in [[CNBC]]'s "Asia's Most High-Profile Weddings", where her wedding was ranked in the top 5.{{cite web|title=Asia's Most High-Profile Weddings|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/42639189/page/1|author=Rajeshni Naidu-Ghelani|date=26 April 2011|work=[[CNBC]]| accessdate = 26 January 2014}}{{cite web|title=Asia's Most High-Profile Weddings|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/42639189/page/6|author=Rajeshni Naidu-Ghelani|date=26 April 2011|work=[[CNBC]]| accessdate = 26 January 2014}} On 13 June 2010, Siti and her husband, Datuk Seri Khalid, was recognised by [[E! News|E! News Asia]] as the Third Most Powerful Celebrity Couple in Asia, behind Chinese entertainer couple, [[Simon Yam]] and wife, [[Qi Qi (model)|Qi Qi]] and Bollywood superstar couple, [[Aishwarya Rai]] and husband, [[Abhishek Bachchan]].{{cite web|title=Video: E! News Report: Asia’s Most Powerful Couple In Asia|url=http://www.aishwarya-spice.com/video-e-news-asias-most-powerful-couples/|date=13 June 2010|work=Aishwarya-Spice.com|accessdate=3 September 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029163520/http://www.aishwarya-spice.com/video-e-news-asias-most-powerful-couples|archive-date=29 October 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=E! News report: #1 Powerful Couple in Asia-Aishwarya and Abhishek|url=http://www.pinkvilla.com/entertainmenttags/abhishek-bachchan/e-news-report-1-powerful-couple-asiaaishwarya-and-abhishek|date=13 June 2010|work=PinkVilla.com|accessdate = 3 September 2010}} In December, 2015, Siti suffered a miscarriage two months into her pregnancy prompting her to share her difficult fertility journey with the public. In October, 2017 after seeking longterm treatment at a fertility centre, Siti announced via social media live that she was expecting her first child with Datuk Khalid. Their daughter was born on 19 March 2018 via caesarean section. The new parents said they chose Monday as the delivery date for their first child as it coincided with the Prophet [[Muhammad]]’s birthday.{{cite news|url=http://www.mstar.com.my/hiburan/berita-hiburan/2017/10/13/siti-nurhaliza-hamil/|title=Siti Nurhaliza Buka Rahsia Hamil 4 Bulan|accessdate=14 October 2017|work=Mohd Al-Qayum Azizi|publisher=''[[mSTAR Online]]''|date=13 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/lifestyle/malaysian-singer-siti-nurhaliza-pregnant-with-her-first-child-9309592|title=Malaysian singer Siti Nurhaliza pregnant with her first child|accessdate=14 October 2017|work=|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]|date=13 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/malaysian-singer-siti-nurhaliza-confirms-her-pregnancy-18040|title=Malaysian singer Siti Nurhaliza confirms her pregnancy|accessdate=14 October 2017|work=Nirmal Narayanan|publisher=International Business Times|date=13 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.astroawani.com/berita-hiburan/sah-siti-nurhaliza-hamil-157905|title=Sah! Siti Nurhaliza hamil|accessdate=14 October 2017|work=|publisher=[[Astro Awani]]|date=13 October 2017}} ==Discography== {{Main|Siti Nurhaliza discography}} {{see also|List of songs recorded by Siti {{Infobox organization |name = Society for Economic Measurement |image = SEM logo 1.jpg |size = |caption =The logo of the Society for Economic Measurement |motto = |formation = August 24, 2013 |members = |status = Learned society in [[economics]] |purpose = To promote research on economic measurement, using advanced tools from economic theory, econometrics, aggregation theory, experimental economics, mathematics, and statistics<ref>[http://sem.society.cmu.edu/home.html SEM Home Page message]</ref> |headquarters = |region_served = United States, Internationally |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[William A. Barnett]], [[University of Kansas]] and [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org/ Center for Financial Stability] |main_organ = Executive Committee<ref>[http://sem.society.cmu.edu/officers.html SEM Executive Committee]</ref> |budget = |website =[http://sem.society.cmu.edu/home.htm sem.society.cmu.edu] }}
The '''Society for Economic Measurement''', or '''SEM''', is a scientific [[learned society]] in the field of [[economics]]. It was founded on August 24, 2013 by [[William A. Barnett]] in order to "promote research on economic measurement, using advanced tools from economic theory, econometrics, aggregation theory, experimental economics, mathematics, and statistics".<ref>[http://sem.society.cmu.edu/home.html SEM Home Page]</ref> Nobel Laureate [[James Heckman]] will take over as the society's second president in 2019 for a three-year term in office. The goal of the SEM is to promote in economics—given the constraints of a [[social science]]—the implementation of the strict rules of measurement and data gathering standards used in the [[physical sciences]]. [[Carnegie Mellon University]], the [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org/ Center for Financial Stability], and the [[University of Kansas]] are sponsors of the society.
==Activities== * The '''inaugural conference''' of the SEM was held at the [http://www.chicagobooth.edu/about/campuses/hyde-park Harper Center] of the [[University of Chicago]]'s [[Booth School of Business]] on August 18–20, 2014.<ref>[http://sem.society.cmu.edu/conferences.html SEM Conference]</ref> It was co-sponsored by the [[Becker Friedman Institute for Research in Economics|Becker Friedman Institute]] at the [[University of Chicago]]. * The 2nd SEM conference was held at the OECD in [[Paris]] on July 22–24, 2015. * The 3rd SEM conference was held in [http://sem.society.cmu.edu/Thessaloniki.html Thessaloniki, Greece] on July 6–8, 2016. * The 4th SEM conference was held at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] on July 26–28, 2017. * The 5th SEM conference will be held at [[Xiamen University]] on Xiamen Island in China in June 2108. * The 6th SEM Conference will be held at [[Goethe University]] in Frankfurt, with cosponsorship by the [[European Central Bank]], on August 16–18, 2019.
== SEM Fellows == The full list of the 2013-2014 SEM Fellows is posted here: [http://sem.society.cmu.edu/SEM_Fellows.asp SEM 2013-2014 Fellows].
==Officers== '''A. <u>EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE:</u>'''
'''1. <u>President:</u>''' * [[William A. Barnett|W. A. Barnett]], U. of Kansas and Center for Financial Stability, NY City '''2. <u>Vice Presidents:</u>''' * [[Yves Balasko]], University of York, UK * [[Ernst Berndt (MIT professor)]], MIT * [[Walter Erwin Diewert]], U of British Columbia, Canada * Ester Faia, Goethe University, Germany * Kaye Husbands Fealing, Georgia Institute of Technology * Dennis Fixler, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Department of Commerce * Barbara Fraumeni, U. of Southern Maine; Central U. of Finance and Economics, Beijing * [[Dale Jorgenson]], Harvard * Ken Judd, Stanford (Hoover) * [[Julia Lane]], New York University * [[Jacques Mairesse (economist)|Jacques Mairesse]], CREST (ENSAE, Paris), UNU-MERIT (Maastricht University, Maastricht) * [[J. Peter Neary]], Oxford U., U.K. * Paul Schreyer, Deputy Director, OECD Statistics Directorate, Paris * Apostolos Serletis, U. of Calgary, Canada * [[Karl Shell]], Cornell * Marcel Timmer, University of Groningen, Netherlands * Sevin Yeltekin, Carnegie Mellon U. '''3. <u>Members at Large:</u>''' * [[James Heckman]], U. of Chicago and University College, Dublin '''4. <u>Member by Appointment of the Center for Financial Stability:</u>''' * Lawrence Goodman, President, [http://www.centerforfinancialstability.org/ Center for Financial Stability], NY City '''5. <u>Secretary-Treasurer:</u>''' * Stephen Spear, Carnegie Mellon U. '''B. <u>COUNCIL:</u>'''
<u>'''Charter Council Members:'''</u> * Bert Balk, Rotterdam School of Management, Netherlands * Marcelle Chauvet, U. of California Riverside * Robert Feenstra, U. of California at Davis * Kevin Fox, U. of New South Wales * Steve Hanke, Johns Hopkins U. * [[Jonathan Haskel]], Imperial College, London, U.K. * Robert Hill, U. of Graz, Austria * Charles Hulten, U. of Maryland * Robert Inklaar, U. of Groningen, Netherlands * Peter Ireland, Boston College * Fredj Jawadi, U. of Évry and France Business School, France * Koji Nomura, Keio U., Tokyo, Japan * Lee Ohanian, UCLA * Philippe de Peretti, University of Paris 1, Sorbonne, France * Prasada Rao, University of Queensland, Australia * Stephen Turnovsky, U. of Washington * Myrna Wooders, Vanderbilt University * Nicholas Yannelis, U. of Iowa
==References== <references />

revision.text:
'''Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP) Entrepreneurship Corner (ECorner)''' (Formerly Educators Corner) is a free online archive of entrepreneurship resources for teaching and learning. The purpose of the project is to support and encourage faculty around the world who teach entrepreneurship to future scientists, engineers, managers, and others. The site has been developed by a team of educators, entrepreneurs, engineers, and designers at the Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP). The project has been financially supported by Stanford University and a number of sponsors. Other collaborators in its creation include the Stanford Center for Professional Development and Stanford Video.<ref>http://ecorner.stanford.edu/about.html, STVP Entrepreneurship Corner</ref>
==Website content== The design of the archive is based on feedback from entrepreneurship educators regarding the challenges faced when teaching entrepreneurship. Resources include video clips, podcasts, syllabi, books, conferences, and listings of entrepreneurship programs.
==Partners== The STVP Entrepreneurship Corner is partnering with London Business School, the Strascheg Center for Entrepreneurship in Munich, and the Centre for Scientific Enterprise Limited (CSEL) in developing shared resources and content.
==About STVP== The Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP) is the entrepreneurship education and research center located within the School of Engineering at Stanford University. The center is hosted by the department of Management Science and Engineering. The purpose of the center is to accelerate high-technology entrepreneurship research and education for engineers and scientists worldwide. STVP supports academic research on high-technology entrepreneurship and teaches a wide range of courses to science and engineering students on campus. Outreach programs include annual conferences, campus-wide collaboration, and dissemination of teaching content through the Entrepreneurship Corner website.
== Speakers == Speakers include [[Guy Kawasaki]] ([[The Art of the Start]] Author), [[Mark Zuckerberg]] ([[Facebook]] founder) and [[Larry Page]] ([[Google]] Co-founder). There are also speakers from companies including [[Mozilla]], [[Hewlett Packard]], [[Electronic Arts]] and [[Tesla Motors]].<ref>http://ecorner.stanford.edu/speakersAuthors.html STVP Entrepreneurship Corner Speakers</ref>
==See also == * [[List of educational video websites]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://ecorner.stanford.edu/podcasts.html Stanford Entrepreneurship Corner Videos and Podcasts], Stanford Technology Ventures Program
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stanford Technology Ventures Program}} [[Category:Entrepreneurship organizations]] [[Category:Stanford University]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Otheruses|Stellar wind (disambiguation)}} {{NSA surveillance|1}} {| style="float:right" |[[File:Nsa-ig-draft-report.pdf|thumb|2009 OIG Draft Report on Stellar Wind]] |} "'''Stellar Wind'''" (or "'''Stellarwind'''") was the [[code name]] of a warrantless surveillance program begun under the [[George W. Bush administration]]'s [[President's Surveillance Program]] (PSP).<ref name =OIG1>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/27/nsa-inspector-general-report-document-data-collection NSA Inspector General report on the President's Surveillance Program], March 24, 2009, page 10, note 3.</ref> The [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) program was approved by [[George W. Bush|President Bush]] shortly after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]], and was revealed by [[Thomas Tamm]] to ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2008.<ref name=TimeMueller>[http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2067995-2,00.html "Is the FBI Up to the Job 10 Years After 9/11?"] April 28, 2011</ref><ref name="newsweek1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/174601|title=The Fed Who Blew the Whistle: Is he a hero or a criminal?|last=Isikoff|first=Michael|date=December 13, 2008|work=Newsweek|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081215105850/http://www.newsweek.com/id/174601|archivedate=December 15, 2008}}</ref> Stellar Wind was a prelude to new legal structures that allowed President Bush and President [[Barack Obama]] to reproduce each of those programs and expand their reach.<ref name=wapoarch>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/us-surveillance-architecture-includes-collection-of-revealing-internet-phone-metadata/2013/06/15/e9bf004a-d511-11e2-b05f-3ea3f0e7bb5a_story.html|title=U.S. surveillance architecture includes collection of revealing Internet, phone metadata|work=The Washington Post|date=June 16, 2013|first=Barton|last=Gellman}}</ref>
== Program scope == The program's activities involved [[data mining]] of a large database of the communications of American citizens, including e-mail communications, telephone conversations, financial transactions, and internet activity.<ref name="newsweek1"/> [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]], a retired technical leader with the NSA, discussed some of the architectural and operational elements of the program at the [[Chaos Communication Congress|2012 Chaos Communication Congress]].<ref name="newsweek2">{{cite AV media |people=Binney, William |title=29C3 Panel: Jesselyn Radack, Thomas Drake, William Binney on whistleblowing and surveillance |medium=YouTube Video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XDM3MqHln8U |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |format=Flash |time=1:03:00 |publisher=Chaos Communication Congress |location=Hamburg, Germany}}</ref>
The intelligence community also was able to obtain from the [[U.S. Treasury Department]] suspicious activity reports, or "SARS", which are reports of activities such as large cash transactions that are submitted by financial institutions under anti-money laundering rules.<ref name="newsweek1" />
There were internal disputes within the [[U.S. Justice Department]] about the legality of the program, because data is collected for large numbers of people, not just the subjects of [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] (FISA) warrants.<ref name="newsweek3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/174602|title=Now We Know What the Battle Was About|last=Klaidman|first=Daniel |date=December 13, 2008|work=Newsweek|archiveurl=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/12/13/now-we-know-what-the-battle-was-about.html|archivedate=November 13, 2010}}</ref><ref name =ars1>{{cite news |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/07/what-the-ashcroft-hospital-showdown-on-nsa-spying-was-all-about/|title=What the Ashcroft 'Hospital Showdown' on NSA spying was all about|author=Sanchez, Julian|date=July 29, 2013|accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref> During the Bush Administration, the Stellar Wind cases were referred to by FBI agents as "pizza cases" because many seemingly suspicious cases turned out to be food takeout orders. According to then-[[FBI Director]] [[Robert Mueller]], approximately 99% of the cases led nowhere, but "it's that other 1% that we've got to be concerned about".<ref name=TimeMueller/>
== 2004 conflict == From a report by the inspectors general of six US intelligence agencies that was declassified in September 2015, it became clear that President Bush had originally authorized the collection of telephone and e-mail metadata only if one end of the communications was foreign or when there was a link to terrorism. But in 2004, the Justice Department found out that the NSA was apparently also collecting the metadata of purely domestic communications, after which President Bush declared that NSA had always been allowed to do so, but that analysts were only allowed to look at metadata related to terrorism. With this revised formulation, Bush reauthorized the program on March 11, 2004.<ref name=NYTimes2015-09-20/>
In 2004, the head of the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC), [[Jack Landman Goldsmith]], wrote at least two legal memos authorizing the program, "We conclude only that when the nation has been thrust into an armed conflict by a foreign attack on the United States and the president determines in his role as commander in chief ... that it is essential for defense against a further foreign attack to use the [wiretapping] capabilities of the [National Security Agency] within the United States, he has inherent constitutional authority" to order warrantless wiretapping—"an authority that Congress cannot curtail," Goldsmith wrote in a 108-page memo dated May 6, 2004. In March 2004, the OLC concluded the e-mail program was not legal, and then-Acting Attorney General [[James Comey]] refused to reauthorize it.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=Legal memos released on Bush-era justification for warrantless wiretapping|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/legal-memos-released-on-bush-era-justification-for-warrantless-wiretapping/2014/09/05/91b86c52-356d-11e4-9e92-0899b306bbea_story.html|work=Washington Post|date=6 September 2014}}</ref>
== Revelations == In March 2012 ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine published "The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)" talking about a vast new [[Utah Data Center|NSA facility in Utah]] and said, "For the first time, a former NSA official has gone on the record to describe the program, codenamed Stellarwind, in detail," naming the official William Binney, a former NSA code breaker. Binney went on to say that the NSA had highly secured rooms that tap into major switches, and satellite communications at both AT&T and Verizon.<ref name="Wired Magazine" >{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1|title=The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)|last=Bamford|first=James|date=March 15, 2012|work=Wired|accessdate=March 15, 2012}}</ref> The article suggested that the supposedly-terminated Stellar Wind continues as an active program. This conclusion was supported by the exposure of [[Room 641A]] in AT&T's operations center in San Francisco in 2006.
In June 2013 the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' and the ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' published an Office of the Inspector General ([[Office of Inspector General (United States)|OIG]]) draft report, dated March 2009, leaked by [[Edward Snowden]] detailing the Stellar Wind program.<ref name =OIG1/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/national-security-agency-inspector-general-draft-report/277/|title = NSA inspector general report on email and internet data collection under Stellar Wind|date= March 9, 2009|accessdate= August 1, 2013}}</ref> No doubt remained about the continuing nature of the surveillance program.
In September 2014 ''[[The New York Times]]'' asserted, "Questions persist after the release of a newly declassified version of a legal memo approving the National Security Agency's Stellarwind program, a set of warrantless surveillance and data collection activities secretly authorized after the [[September 11 attacks|terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001]]." as an introductory headline summary with a link. The accompanying article addressed the release of a newly declassified version of the May 2004 memo.<ref>Savage, Charlie, [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/07/us/redactions-in-us-memo-leave-doubts-on-data-surveillance-program.html?emc=edit_th_20140907&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=68634180&_r=0 "Redactions in U.S. Memo Leave Doubts on Data Surveillance Program"], ''The New York Times'', Sunday, September 7, 2014, p. A17</ref> Note was made that the bulk of the program—the telephone, Internet, and e-mail surveillance of American citizens—remained secret until the revelations by [[Edward Snowden]], that to date, significant portions of the memo remain redacted in the newly released version, and that doubts and questions about its legality persist.
== See also == {{Portal|Government of the United States|Intelligence|mass surveillance}} * [[2013 mass surveillance disclosures]] * ''[[Hepting v. AT&T]]'' (warrantless wiretapping case) * [[MUSCULAR]] * [[NSA call database]] * [[NSA electronic surveillance program]] * [[NSA warrantless surveillance controversy]] * [[President's Surveillance Program#Ashcroft hospital bedside meeting|President's Surveillance Program: Ashcroft hospital bedside meeting]] * [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=NYTimes2015-09-20> {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/21/us/politics/george-w-bush-made-retroactive-nsa-fix-after-hospital-room-showdown.html?_r=1 | title = George W. Bush Made Retroactive N.S.A. 'Fix' After Hospital Room Showdown | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = 2015-09-20 | author = [[Charlie Savage]] | archiveurl = | archivedate = 2016-08-13 | deadurl = No }} </ref> }}
== External links == * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/27/nsa-inspector-general-report-document-data-collection NSA inspector general report on email and internet data collection under Stellar Wind – full document], The Guardian, June 27, 2013. * [[Laura Poitras|Poitras, Laura]]. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/23/opinion/the-national-security-agencys-domestic-spying-program.html?_r=2&ref=opinion ''The Program'']. Nytimes.com, Op-Docs, August 22, 2012.
{{National Security Agency}}
[[Category:National Security Agency]] [[Category:Applied data mining]]

The '''Telstra Business Awards''' is an Australian awards programme started in 1992. The '''Telstra Business Awards''' is an independent Awards programme designed to recognise and promote excellence, best practice and innovation in the business community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telstrabusinesswomensawards.com/ |title=Telstra Business Women's Awards |publisher=Telstrabusinesswomensawards.com |date= |accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Irving |first=Will |url=http://exchange.telstra.com.au/2013/09/09/the-telstra-business-awards-tv-show/ |title=The Telstra Business Awards TV show | Telstra Exchange |publisher=Exchange.telstra.com.au |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
